lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Query parameters are a common way to pass information from one web page to another in the form of key-value pairs.

For example, in a URL like https://my-app.com?search=music, search=music is a query parameter.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access query parameters in a React component, we use the useLocation hook from the react-router-dom package.

Make sure to pick import followed by { and then useLocation, }, from, "react-router-dom".

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The useLocation hook returns an object containing the current URL's information.

When we log it, we see the current path name "/" among other info.

Make sure to pick const followed by location and then =, useLocation().

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To extract the search query from it, we use location.search.

To transform the search string into a usable format, create a new URLSearchParams object from location.search.

Make sure to pick new, followed by URLSearchParams, and finally location.search.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
With the URLSearchParams object, use the get method to access specific query parameters by name.

Get the value of the parameter called "search" by using query.get("search").

Make sure to pick query, followed by .get, and finally "search".

lessons.title: a
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can query as many query parameters as we want.

Check for a query parameter with the key "region", and display it.

Make sure to pick region followed by query.get and then "region", region.

lessons.title: a - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
There is no guarantee a query parameter will be attached to the URL. If we try to get a parameter that is not provided, we'll receive null.

Try to access the query parameter "friend" to log and render it.

Make sure to pick friend followed by query.get and then "friend", friend, friend.

lessons.title: a - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We should never assume that a query parameter will be provided. Allways check if there is a value.

Use conditional rendering to display a default value if friend is null.

Make sure to pick friend, followed by ||, and finally "nobody".

lessons.title: Lesson #15 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Another good way to ensure we don't render broken content is to use default values for the query parameters we need.

Set "Pepsi" as the default value if we don't receive a value for the search parameter brand.

Make sure to pick brand followed by || and then "Pepsi", brand.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Access query parameters in a URL and display their values on the page using React.

Make sure to pick query followed by .get and then "item", {, item, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the output when the following code is executed with the URL https://my-react-app.com?color=green?

Favorite color: greenFavorite color: redFavorite color: blueFavorite color: null

Favorite color: green.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Demonstrate conditional rendering with query parameters in a React app.

Make sure to pick name followed by searchParams and then .get("name"), name, ?, name, :.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be displayed if the following code is executed with the URL https://my-react-app.com?planet=Mars?

Exploring place: EarthExploring place: MarthExploring place: VenusExploring place: null

Exploring place: Earth.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent: Integrate multiple query parameters and display them using React.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is a method to obtain all query parameters from a URL?

URLSearchParamsuseNavigatesetQuerylocation.pathname

Make sure to pick URLSearchParams.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Define and use a default value for an optional query parameter in a React component.

Make sure to pick ||, followed by "dog", and finally pet.
